questions.question: What inference rule has the form p→q, p ⊢ q?
questions.explanation: Modus ponens is a valid inference rule that affirms the antecedent.

questions.question: What inference rule has the form p→q, ¬q ⊢ ¬p?
questions.explanation: Modus tollens is a valid inference using the contrapositive principle.

questions.question: What fallacy has the form p→q, q ⊢ p?
questions.explanation: Affirming the consequent is an invalid inference pattern.

questions.question: What fallacy has the form p→q, ¬p ⊢ ¬q?
questions.explanation: Denying the antecedent is an invalid inference pattern.

questions.question: What inference rule chains implications: p→q, q→r ⊢ p→r?
questions.explanation: Hypothetical syllogism expresses the transitive property of implication.

questions.question: What inference rule has the form p∨q, ¬p ⊢ q?
questions.explanation: Disjunctive syllogism eliminates one disjunct to conclude the other.

questions.question: What paradox states that a false antecedent makes any implication true?
questions.explanation: This counterintuitive truth condition is a feature of material implication.

questions.question: What type of implication is based on necessity in modal logic?
questions.explanation: Strict implication requires the consequent to be necessarily true when the antecedent is.

questions.question: What inference rule has the form (p→q)∧(r→s), p∨r ⊢ q∨s?
questions.explanation: Constructive dilemma combines conditional reasoning with disjunction.
